Cédric Beust ♔ wrote:

>On 8/28/06, Andrew McDonagh <yahoogroups@...> wrote:
>  
>
>>I rely upon Acceptance tests to test this kind of 3rd party integration
>>issues. I find it make my unit tests smaller, easier to write, faster to
>>run, adding a layer of indirection between the application code and its
>>dependencies, etc.
>>    
>>
>
>
>It will probably make your unit tests smaller, but when the bug happens, it
>will take you longer to isolate it because only your acceptance tests will
>fail, and probably in mysterious ways (such as leaking connections).
>
>I prefer for my tests to catch bugs as soon as possible (especially in this
>case, where invoking close() will not make them that much slower).
>
>  
>
It's not like that, though. Really, if you make your UTs look like ATs, 
i.e., they run all of these external subsystems, you've just pushed the 
issue of isolating the problem into the UTs. If you write your UTs 
isolated, you have a binary chop. When your UTs pass and your ATs fail, 
it helps you figure out where to look.

And, actually, some people go further. They write tests for APIs that 
they use from other development teams or from vendors.. it helps them 
discover early when libraries change behavior without documenting it, 
and that can save considerable time over development. I don't know 
whether I'd call that a "trinary chop," but it's tempting :-)
